description.narrative: Association of African Universities (AAU) är en organisation och ett huvudforum för konsultation, informationsutbyte och samarbete mellan högre utbildningsinstitutioner i Afrika. Aktiviteter som kommer att få Sida stöd är följande; 1) Konferenser; 2) Spridning av information om högre utbildning i Afrika; samt 3)Akademisk rörlighet och stipendier till forskarstudenter.

The Association of African Universities (AAU)is an organisation and forum for consultation, information exchange and cooperation between higher education institutions in Africa. AAU's activities to be supported by Sida are as follows; 1) conferences; 2) dissemination of information on higher education in Africa and 3) Academic mobility and scholarship award to research students.

The intended outcome is to enhance the quality and relevance of higher education in Africa and strengthen its contribution to Africa's development. The intervention logic is to build capacity of AAU member institutions and the secretariat, as well as to develop stronger relations with the African Union Commission, regional and sub-regional bodies, development partners, university communities and student associations within and outside Africa. The continuing emphasis on stakeholder relations and university-industry linkages, more specifically, has the potential to meet the educational and development needs of the continent.

description.narrative: Summary and examples of achieved results December 2013-June 2020: 1. AAU Statutory meetings Goals: 1) Bring research results to a wider group of stakeholders and discuss the vision and the new Strategic Plan of the organization. 2) Examine themes of major concern to African Higher Education and Research. 3) Exchange ideas, information and experiences between member institutions. 4) Take stock of decisions reached at the General Conference. Results: During the period four statutory meetings have been held: Two Conference of Rectors, Vice Chancellors and Presidents of African Universities (CORVIP) and two General Conferences. The conferences brings together a number of stakeholders in higher education, for example university leaders, policy makers, ministries, development partners, academics and researchers. Recommendations from the these conferences are shared and disseminated widely among higher education stakeholders. Several new activities and collaborations have emanated out from the conferences. 2. Staff Development Goal: To ensure effective coordination and correspondence with researchers, administrators, and financial controllers and an efficient implementation of the Strategic Plan. Results: Over the reporting period, a total of six staff training events were held for various categories of AAU staff on Project Management, French Language, Change management, Performance management, Review of the 2016-2020 Strategic Plan, Conflict resolution, Effective Communication and External Relations. The staff training sessions were undertaken during staff retreats. As a result the French language proficiency of AAU staff has been enhanced, the strategic plan 2016-2020 was finalized and the Human Resources Manual of AAU was developed and the Organizational Annual Appraisal Form was revised. 3. Information Resources on Higher Education Goals: 1) Management of a library on Higher Education, including query and answer services 2) Production and dissemination of publications and information on higher education 3) Subscription to intelligent systems for information to support the production of the AAU News letter 4) Software Licensing/System development and maintenance Results: International conferences on higher education in Africa were held in response to the result areas: "Engaging with African and International Partners in Development for Improved Collaboration", "Knowledge generation, management and dissemination" and "Strengthening HEIs' delivery capacity in Africa". One example of a successful conference was a regional conference on the theme Changing Higher Education Landscape in Africa: New funding paradigms was held in Togo in 2014. After the conference a book titled Toward Innovative Models for Funding Higher Education in Africa, was published. The identification of innovative and indigenous approaches for funding higher education and research; compilation and dissemination of best practices; development of common strategies for monitoring and supporting new mobilisation strategies have intensified as a result of the conference and the book. AAU is holding regular resource mobilization workshops to date. During the programme period AAU has improved it's website and created several web-based services. AAU has also increased it's presence on social media and have accounts on Facebook, YouTube, twitter, blogs and Flickr. The platforms are used to spread information about AAU's events and disseminate messages from events. AAU's internal system for project management has also been improved, this include for example online application and review systems, management information systems and online conference management systems for attendees and abstracts. AAU has also subscribed to intelligence systems to track and news on African higher education, which the association includes in AAU weekly newsletter. 4. AAU Public Broadcasting Goals: Programme promotion and Equipment procurement. Results: Under the AAU Public Broadcasting activity there are mainly two activities, AAU TV and webinars. The number of views have dramatically increased over the years. AAU has collaborated with Partnership for African Social and Governance Research (PASGR) and the Regional Forum for Capacity Building in Agriculture (RUFORUM) to help beef up programme content. AAU has received funding from Carnegie Corporation for training of staff to improve their efficiency and develop a 5-year AAU TV Strategic Plan. The reception of the AAU TV by the higher education community has been very positive and encouraging. 5. Academic mobility Goals: Promote interchange, contacts and co-operation among university institutions; Supervision of graduate theses and visiting scholars' scheme for member institutions; Financial support to post graduate studies (Masters and PhD students). Results: The intention with the activity was to promote staff exchange, that staff at the member universities were given the possibility to teach at a another university. The receiving university departments were given a chance to gain from a competent lecturer. During the project 43 staff exchange missions were undertaken and 33 university departments in West, Southern and Eastern Africa benefited. In 2016 an online application system was introduced. The follow-up reports from teachers and university departments show that collaborative research work and networking among teaching colleagues have been established. The activity Small Grants Programme has been open for applications from graduate students, researchers, lecturers, and staff registered for PhD or MPhil in the AAU member universities. The aim with the programme has been to make it possible for master and PhD-students to finalise ongoing studies and dissertations. Grants have been given to students in a number of fields in social and natural sciences and engineering. (Humanities have not been included). During the period a number of 185 grants were awarded of which 75% went to PhD students and 25% to master students. Many of the recipients have completed their education and become lecturers, heads of departments, deans, directors at various sectors of the African economy. 6. ICT & DATAD Goals: To increase the volume of online access to African scholarly publications and Improve the application of this technology in research, teaching and management. Results: The focus in ICT and DATAD has been on increasing ICT infrastructure for knowledge management, improving capacity for knowledge production and management, increasing access to information of knowledge produced by HEI and enhancing standardised data collection in HEIs. During the period 2013-2017 AAU arranged five ICT training workshops. The trainings resulted in that the universities improved their network securities and improved efficiency in the use of their bandwidth. AAU also facilitated the creation of two National Research and Education Networks - RERBenin (Benin) and FasoREN (Burkina Faso). The process for the formation of an NREN in Liberia was also initiated. AAU also facilitated four annual AfREN (African National Research and Education Network) meetings to deliberate on how the Regional Research and Education Networks could best support research and education and promote and facilitate for affordable and reliable internet and ICT related services to Universities. Through the DATAD activity AAU has set up or upgraded 20 institutional repositories with improved content to increase the volume of African scholarly publications available. The DATAD activity has resulted in that access has been given to Africa's scholarly works (theses, dissertations and publications) both full text and abstracts. The number of DATAD member institutions has increased from 11 to 45. 7. University-Industry Linkages Goals: Promote closer cooperation between universities and industries The university-industry linkages programme has seeked to address AAU's goal of strengthening HEI's Delivery Capacity in Africa with a focus on the linkage to the productive sector. In the programme Sida has funded the activity "The AAU Graduate Internship Programme" which aims at provide internship grants to students prior graduation. During internship students can practice skills and get used to working life but also apply the theory they have learnt in their studies. The internship programme began in 2014 and was open to students from all fields. AAU has used three selection criterias: focus on post-graduates students, authorisation letter from Head of Department of the applicant's university as well as an official acceptance letter from the authority or firm wishing to host the intern, detailed CV with consideration given to applicants with no practical work experience. AAU's goal has also been that 40% of the beneficiaries should be female, not more than 10 applicants per country, at least 30% from Francophone institutions. The payment to beneficiaries has been done in two tranches, the first one in the beginning and the second one after completion of the internship and submission of an evaluation report by the host institution or firm. Between 2014-2017 a number of 248 beneficiaries, 62% men and 38% women, were awarded internship grants. Many of the grantees reports on very positive experiences from their internship period. 8. Empowerment of women and webinar series Goals: Support women in science and AAU Webinar series Results: In 2019 the AAU issued a call for consultancy by a senior scholar to conduct a study on the Factors that Affect Female Participation in Science in African Universities. The study sought to identify empirically those factors, social, economic, political and cultural that influence female participation in science programmes in Africa. The findings from the study was presented at the International Conference for Women in Leadership Positions in Higher Education (WoLPHE). The theme of the conference was Women's Participation in Science Programmes in Africa and was held on November 26-29, 2019 in Abuja, Nigeria. The conference provided an opportunity for women in STEM to discuss the findings in the study and inspire and empower the next generation of women in STEM to drive change and innovation. During the period AAU initiated five webinars on different issues of interest for African Higher Education with the aim of promoting intellectual engagement. The numbers of webinars was later on increased to 15. The title of the first webinar in May 2019 was Harnessing Diaspora Resources to Improve Quality of African Higher Education. From 2017 more than 30 webinars have been held. The webinars have been facilitated by international higher education resource persons. The webinar series have attracted funding from Development of Education (ADEA) and Carnegie Coorporation of New York. 9. Promoting Higher Education Networks Goals: Supporting Higher Education Networks Results: During the period AAU has established partnerships with several different partners. For example, AAU has partnered with Partnership for African Social and Governance Research (PASGAR) to source for AAU TV content in Nigeria and Kenya and with RUFORUM (Regional Universities Forum for Capacity Building in Agriculture) for agricultural content. AAU has also partnered with OBREAL Global, DAAD, EUA (European Universities Association) and ENQA (European Association for Quality Assurance and Accreditation Initiative). The initiative sought to support harmonization of higher education programmes and create a revitalized, distinctive, attractive and globally competitive African higher education space, through enhanced intra-African collaboration. AAU also entered into partnership with the African Academy of Science (AAS) to jointly execute the IDRC funded Research Management project of Science Granting Councils in specific areas of research management, namely research excellence and the use of specific tools such as Research Quality Plus framework. 10. Grant activity: Development of New strategic plan: 2020-2025 Goals: Stakeholder Consultations on New Strategic Plan and Development and Approval of New Strategic Plan. Results: The 2016-2025 Strategic Plan expired in June 2020. The process of developing a new strategic plan started 2019. The development of a new strategic plan for 2020-2025 was done through a reflective and consultative process guided by a consultant. 11. Leveraging the Sida support during COVID-19 Goal: Supporting African HEIs to keep their teaching and learning doors open during COVID-19. Results: The Covid-19 pandemic created major disruption to every aspect of society, including higher education. AAU took a number of steps to assist member universities and the general African higher education community to manage the challenges for HEI during the pandemic. Some of the activities that have taken place are: * issuing guidelines on adopting online and virtual education. * providing information on available resources for virtual education (including open and free platforms which can be used by institutions with budgetary constraints). * organizing virtual seminars for members to help them build capacity for virtual education. * collaborating with Regional Research and Education Networks to help extend affordable bandwidth to institutions. * providing a pool of experts to help individual institutions to transition to online education platforms (assist in areas of course design, delivery and assessments, technical support). * negotiation with software vendors to provide affordable software to our member institutions. * providing free software for members with serious budgetary constraints.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
